subject: RE: [junit] Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... Precisely. ... A compilation can be correct without being optimal.  Optimization often depends upon information which is lost in reducing source code to
messageBody:
On Tue, 30 Sep 2003, Leeuw van der, Tim wrote:

> Compilation is a 'lossy' process in the sense that it's often not 100%
> reversible... So in that sense, information certainly got lost.

Precisely.

> But a correct compiler will preserve sufficient information that
> process-execution complies with what the source code specifies.

A compilation can be correct without being optimal. Optimization often
depends upon information which is lost in reducing source code to object/
bytecode, or only recoverable at significant cost.

> Is Java-bytecode really hugely inefficient compared to how C++ solves the
> problem?

That depends, of course, upon the problem being solved.

--
